revision.text:
'''Aaron ben Gershon Abu Al-Rabi''' of [[Catania]] (also '''Aaron ben Gershon Abualrabi''', '''Aaron Alrabi'''; [[Italian language|Italian]]: ''Aronne Abulrabi'') was a [[History of the Jews in Sicily|Sicilian-Jewish]] scholar, cabalist, and astrologer of the 15th century.
==Life== He was a son-in-law of Don Moses Gabbai, an exile from [[Majorca]]. Aaron was the youngest of five brothers, all rabbinic scholars; the others were Shallum, Baruch, Moses, and Isaac. He studied in [[Treviso]], [[Italy]], and was familiar with the scientific and philosophic literature of his age; he was a good grammarian, and well acquainted with the [[Arabic language]]. Like his father, he believed in astrology, and loved to observe the horoscope. He was also an adept in the [[Kabbalah|Cabala]], though at times his critical spirit came in conflict with its doctrines. On his travels he visited [[Turkey]], [[Egypt]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], [[Damascus]], and [[Feodosiya#Caffa|Kaffa]] in the [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]]. In [[Jerusalem]] he had many disputations with the [[Karaite (Jewish sect)|Karaites]], to which his commentary on the [[Pentateuch]] refers with evident pride, as having vindicated the cause of rabbinical theology. While in [[Rome]] he was admitted to the presence of [[Pope Martin V]], who was surrounded by his cardinals. Martin V was kindly disposed toward the [[Jews]], and often discussed religious questions with them in a friendly manner. On this occasion he propounded to Aaron a number of very pointed questions concerning Biblical and Talmudical passages. Among other things he asked if the use of the [[cherubim]] in the Holy of Holies was not rather antagonistic to the [[You shall not make for yourself an idol|Second Commandment]], which prohibits [[idolatry]]. Aaron in his commentary refers several times to this discussion and to the answers he gave.
==Writer== Coming often in contact with learned Christians, Aaron had many occasions to defend Judaism against the polemics of the Church, on the one hand, and the attacks of the Karaites on the other. It was this unceasing conflict that induced him to write a book, called "Maṭṭeh Aharon" (The Staff of Aaron), in defense of the Law and tradition. Keenly observant, and of an independent and critical spirit, he judged persons and opinions freely and openly. He excels as a writer and as a Bible commentator, and often upbraids the Jews of his native land for their ignorance and hollow pretensions, at the same time pointing with admiration to the numerous Jews of high breeding he has met on his travels. Following the principle of a rational Biblical [[exegesis]], he does not hesitate occasionally to refute [[haggadic]] traditions which seem to conflict with reason and common sense; and at times, like [[Abraham ibn Ezra]] and [[Samuel ben Meir]], he even states his disagreement with [[halakic]] interpretation. He was fully conversant with the views of the Karaites and [[Samaritans]] and eager, in his explanation of the Bible, to refute now Christian and now [[Muslim]] doctrines. He boldly exposes errors wherever he finds them, claiming "that it is more honorable for the wise to commit an error than knowingly to misrepresent the truth."
Nor does he shrink from pointing out the blemishes he finds in the character of the Patriarchs. Being guided solely by a love of truth, he, as a matter of course, does not spare such great Bible commentators as [[Rashi]] and [[Nahmanides]]. For the former Aaron entertained a very high regard; of the latter he frequently says, "With due deference to his honor, he misunderstood the Talmud" (see his commentary upon Gen. xxvii. 22; Ex. xxiii. 11, xxv. 9). Like Samuel ben Meir and Maimonides, he explains the law, "Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother's milk" (Ex. xxiii. 19), as a warning against a certain idolatrous practise. Notwithstanding his liberal mind and his keen investigating spirit, he was held in high esteem by his contemporaries, as may be seen from [[David ben Solomon ibn Abi Zimra|David Abi Zimra's]] mention of him as "Aaron our Rabbi" in No. 10 of his responsa, where he commends him for his liberty of thought. He was a devoted Jew, who deeply deplored the political and social condition of the Jews of his time, and all the more fervently gave expression to his hope for the speedy advent of the Messiah. For his cabalistic views he quotes [[Recanate]] and [[Joseph Sar Shalom]], but not the [[Zohar]].
==Works== Aaron states that he wrote a [[Hebrew grammar]] entitled "''Ha-Meyasher''" (''The Leveler of the Road''); "''Maṭṭeh Aharon''," referred to above, a cabalistic or metaphysical work; "''Nezer ha-Ḳodesh''" (''The Crown of Holiness''); "''Peraḥ ha-Elohut''" (''The Blossoming of the Godhead''), probably of a similar character, and "''Sefer ha-Nefesh''" (''The Book of the Soul''). All of these works are known only through his own quotations in his supercommentary on Rashi. This work, published from an incomplete manuscript, together with another supercommentary on Rashi by [[Samuel Almosnino]], by [[Moses Albelda]], and by [[Jacob Canizal]], is one of the earliest books printed at Constantinople, and is therefore very rare. According to his own testimony, it was written in 1420 (as Perles has shown); but he intended to compose, or, as Perles thinks, actually did compose, a larger commentary on the Pentateuch. Perles has furnished ample proof that Aaron Aldabi—or, as he called himself, Aaron Alrabi—was a man of great originality and merit, and it is to be hoped that his lost works will be discovered, and that editions of his commentary, based on clear manuscripts existing in Oxford and elsewhere, will fully vindicate his character, though Graetz and Karpeles, in their histories, have attacked him.
J. H. Schorr, in "Zion," 1840, first called attention to Abu al-Rabi, erroneously calling him Aaron ben Mose Alrabi; but, owing to a misunderstanding of his remarks, he ascribes to him the strange assertion that Moses translated the Pentateuch from the Arabic into Hebrew—a misunderstanding repeated by Grätz, "Gesch. d. Juden" (third edition), viii. 250, and by Karpeles, "Gesch. der Jüdischen Literatur," p. 771—whereas the author, in his commentary upon Gen. xviii. 5, referring to the rabbinical Haggadah that the angels who came to Abraham appeared as Arabs, says that they spoke in Arabic, and that Moses rendered their words in Hebrew—a remark which he repeats in his comments upon Gen. xxiv. 23 and Ex. ii. 10. Zunz, "Z. G.," pp. 518–520, and Steinschneider, "Cat. Bodl.," call him Alrabi. Aaron's true name, however, is given in the acrostic written by him at the end of his published commentary.
==References== *{{Jewish Encyclopedia |article=Aaron ben Gershon Abu Al-Rabi of Catania |url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?letter=A&artid=36#97 |author=Joseph Loeb Sossnitz and [[Kaufmann Kohler]]}}
;Jewish Encyclopedia bibliography *Michael, Or ha-Ḥayyim, No. 281; *J. Perles' article, Aaron Gershon Abulrabi in Rev. Ét. Juives, xxi. 246-269; *Neubauer, Cat. Bodl. Hebr. MSS. No. 2245; *Vogelstein and Rieger, Gesch. d. Juden in Rom, ii. 68. For correct reading of name, see Jew. Quart. Rev. xi. 609.J. L. S.K.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Al-rabi, Aaron ben Gershon Abu}} [[Category:People from Catania]] [[Category:Talmudists]] [[Category:Religious studies scholars]] [[Category:15th-century scholars]] [[Category:Medieval Italian Jews]] [[Category:15th-century Italian people]] [[Category:Italian astrologers]] [[Category:Medieval Jewish scholars]] [[Category:15th-century Jews]]

'''Abraham ben Mordecai Galante''' (died 1560) was an Italian [[kabbalist]] born in [[Rome]] at the beginning of the 16th century. Abraham, like his father [[Galante (pedigree)|Mordecai]] and his brother [[Moses Galante (the Elder)|Moses]] of [[Safed]], is represented by his contemporaries as a man of high character who led a holy life. Being wealthy, he erected a splendid mausoleum over the tomb of [[Simon ben Yoḥai]] at [[Meron, Israel|Meron]], which is still admired.
He was the author of the following works: *''Ḳin'at Setarim,'' a commentary on [[Book of Lamentations|Lamentations]], based upon the [[Zohar]], edited by his son Samuel in the collection ''Ḳol Bokim'' (Venice, 1589) *''Yeraḥ Yakar,'' a commentary on the Zohar, the first part of which ([[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]) was abbreviated by [[Abraham Azulai]] and included in his ''Zohore Ḥammah'' *''Zekut Abot,'' a commentary on the [[Sayings of the Fathers]], mentioned by [[Hananiah of Monselice]] in his commentary on the ''Pirḳe Shirah.'' Galante was also the author of [[halakic]] decisions, which are still extant in manuscript.
==See also== *[[Galante (pedigree)]]
==Jewish Encyclopedia bibliography== *[[Chaim Joseph David Azulai|Azulai]], ''Shem ha-Gedolim'', s.v.; *Michael, ''Or ha-Ḥayyim,'' p. 89; *''Orient. Lit.'' vi.211; *[[Hermann Vogelstein]] and [[Paul Rieger]], ''Geschichte der Juden in Rom'', p. 86.
==References== *{{JewishEncyclopedia|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?letter=G&artid=24|article=Galante}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Galante, Abraham}} [[Category:16th-century births]] [[Category:1560 deaths]] [[Category:16th-century Italian rabbis]] [[Category:Kabbalists]] [[Category:16th-century rabbis]] [[Category:People from Rome]]

revision.text:
In [[Hindu mythology]] '''Atibala''' was a servant of Lanka king [[Ravana]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Williams |first=George M. |year=2008 |title=Handbook of Hindu Mythology |publisher=[[Oxford University Press|OUP USA]] |page=68 |isbn=9780195332612}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Parmeshwaranand |first=Swami |year=2001 |title=Encyclopaedic Dictionary of Puranas, Volume 1 |publisher=Sarup & Sons |page=124 |isbn=9788176252263}}</ref> He was dwarf in nature.
==Birth== Actual birth of Atibala is unknown. He had been created by Ravana as a test-tube baby.
==Death== He had been killed by [[Angada]] during Lanka war.
==Magic== He had knowledge of several magic. One of them is ability to hide in any form of matter. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Hinduism-stub}}
[[Category:Hindu mythology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = Banani International Secondary School<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Bananiscaled 1304242989597735793.jpg]] --> | motto = Let your vision be world embracing, rather than confined to your own self. | established = 1993 | language = [[British English|English]] | type = [[Private school|Private]], [[Boarding school|boarding]], [[Single-sex education|girls' school]] | affiliation = [[Bahá'í Faith]] | grades = 8-12 | authority = Zambia Ministry of Education and [[Cambridge Assessment International Education|CIE]] | town = [[Chisamba]] | country = [[Zambia]] | students = > 160 pupils | school_colors = [[Azure (color)|Azure]], [[white]] and [[black]] {{color box|#007FFF}}{{color box|white}}{{color box|black}} }} '''Banani International Secondary School''' is a [[Boarding school|residential]] [[international school|international]] girls' [[secondary school]] (grades 8-12) in [[Chisamba]], [[Zambia]]. The nearest village is Liteta. It is a non-profit institution and follows the principles of the [[Bahá'í Faith]]. It was inaugurated by the [[William Mmutle Masetlha Foundation]]<ref>[http://www.bic-un.bahai.org/96-0430.htm Two Bahá'í International Community Projects: Cameroon and Zambia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821124805/http://www.bic-un.bahai.org/96-0430.htm |date=2008-08-21 }} report submitted by the Bahá'í International Community Office for the Advancement of Women in April 1996, appears in The Emerging Role of NGOs in African Sustainable Development, published by the United Nations and distributed to participants in the Mid-Term Review of the United Nations New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s (UN-NADAF).</ref> under the direction of the [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Bahá'ís of Zambia<ref>[http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-23.html The Masetlha Foundation: Health, Literacy, & Education in Zambia] 1996-97 edition of The Bahá'í World, pp. 221-226.</ref> and named after [[Hand of the Cause]] Musa Banani.
Banani International Secondary School was ranked 93rd out of the top 100 best high schools in Africa by Africa Almanac in 2003, based upon quality of education, student engagement, strength and activities of alumni, school profile, internet and news visibility.<ref name="top20highschools">{{cite web |url= http://www.africaalmanac.com/top20highschools.html |title= top20highschools |date= 1 October 2003 |website= Africa Almanac |publisher= Africa Almanac |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070114052056/http://www.africaalmanac.com/top20highschools.html#11 |archive-date= 14 January 2007 |dead-url= yes |access-date= 19 June 2016 |quote= The research leading up to the publication of the 100 Best High Schools in Africa began with the launching of the website in December 2000.}}</ref>
== School motto == "Let your vision be world embracing, rather than confined to your own self." Bahá'u'lláh (Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh, p. 87)
== History == Planning began in 1987 for the school, and construction began in 1990. The school opened with 65 students in 1993. It was inaugurated in 1996 with over 100 students, by the Minister of Education, Hon. A. Hambayi, in conjunction with officers of the Bahá’í International Community like [[Kiser Barnes]], Firaydoun Javaheri and others including supporters from [[Austria]] and [[South Africa]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070406125035/http://www.banani.sch.zm/banani.htm Banani School Statement on History and Inauguration]</ref>
There are efforts to expand student population from the area for "day" students for the secondary, as well as a beginning of a primary school.<ref>[http://blog.lib.umn.edu/koom0003/volunteer/2007/08/zambia_banani_seecondary_schoo.html Zambia - Banani School]</ref>
==Facilities== Instructional areas include eight classrooms, a science laboratory, a 30-station computer lab, agricultural areas, and library.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061206022854/http://www.banani.sch.zm/facilities.htm Banani School Statement on Facilities]</ref>
The dormitories hold up to 200 students, with a senior commons (theater and recording studio), play fields, swimming pool, and a campus store. There are facilities for sport.
==Programme== Courses offered include:<ref name="curr">[https://web.archive.org/web/20061004140706/http://www.banani.sch.zm/academicprogramme.htm Banani School Statement on Curriculum]</ref> *[[Additional Mathematics]] *[[Agriculture]] *[[Biology]] *[[Character Development]] *[[Chemistry]] *[[English language|English]] *[[French language|French]] *[[Geography]] *[[History]] *[[Mathematics]] *[[Physics]] *[[World Religions]] *[[Account (accountancy)|Accounts]] *[[Business Studies]] *[[Physical Education]] *[[Computer Studies]] *[[Information Technology]] Most courses come in two forms - "core" for average students, and "supplemental" for advanced students. The school offers Junior youth groups where students are placed into different groups to discuss their lives. Each group is run by an animator who is a girl in senior grades and the other members are junior girls.
==Accreditation and awards== The Zambian Ministry of Education syllabus is used for grades 8 and 9, who then write the junior secondary school leaving exams at the end of grade 9. Grade 10 is a preparatory year and introduction to the grade 11-12 University of Cambridge syllabus which provides students with an [[International General Certificate of Secondary Education]] or the more advanced [[Cambridge IT Skills Diploma]].<ref name="curr"/>
The website African Almanac has reviewed schools in Africa and posted a Top 100 Schools and lists the Banani School as the #93 secondary school for 2003.<ref>[http://www.africaalmanac.com/top20highschools.html#100 The 100 best high schools in Africa, 2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114052056/http://www.africaalmanac.com/top20highschools.html |date=2007-01-14 }}</ref>{{update|date=November 2018}}
There is an annual conference of primary school teachers at the school coordinated by Independent School Association of Zambia (ISAZ)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://rhodesparkschool.net/data/content/view/65/78/ |title=ISAZ Teachers Teachings Teaching Teachers Conference |access-date=2008-01-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115164838/http://rhodesparkschool.net/data/content/view/65/78/ |archive-date=2008-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==School culture== Students wear uniforms all week excluding the weekend. They attend devotion every Sunday. The students are mostly Zambian but there are some who live in other countries. The staff varies in nationality and includes Canadians, Zambians, Congolese, Ugandans, and Americans.
==References== <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.bananischool.org School webpage]
{{coord missing|Zambia}}

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox Governor | name = D. C. Pavate | image = D.C.PavatePic.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date |df=yes|1899|08|02}} | birth_place = [[Mamadapur, Belgaum|Mamadapur]],
[[Gokak|Gokak Taluka]],
[[Belgaum District]],
[[Bombay Presidency]],
[[British India]] | death_date = 31 January 1979
(aged 78) | death_place = [[Bangalore]],
[[Karnataka]],
[[India]] | occupation = [[Professor]], [[Chancellor (education)|vice-Chancellor]], [[Politician]] | nationality = [[India]]n [[File:Flag of India.svg|15px]] | education = [[Master of Arts|M.A]]
[[Bachelor of Arts|B.A]] }} '''Dadappa Chintappa''' "'''D. C.'''" '''Pavate''',[https://www.google.com/search?hl=en&tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=inauthor:%22Dadappa+Chintappa+Pavate%22 Works by Dadappa Chintappa Pavate at Google Books] and [http://www.worldcat.org/title/memoirs-of-an-educational-administrator/oclc/24198797 ''Memoirs of an Educational Administrator'' at Worldcat] (2 August 1899–14 January 1978) was awarded [[Padma Bhushan]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=98YbAAAAIAAJ&q=%22Dadasaheb+Chintamani+Pavate%22&dq=%22Dadasaheb+Chintamani+Pavate%22&as_brr=0&pgis=1 Debates; Official Report] from the Government of India in 1967. He was the [[Chancellor (education)|vice-chancellor]] of the [[Karnatak university]] [[Dharwar]], and the [[Governor]] of [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]]. Pavate was a [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]] [[Wrangler (University of Cambridge)|wrangler]]. Pavate was born in Mamdapur a small village next to [[Gokak]] town. His mother was Shantamma. His father was a farmer. Pavate completed primary schooling from Mamdapur and high school from Gokak. He stood first in B.A Mathematics to [[Rajaram College]], [[Kolhapur]] of [[University of Mumbai]] then. Pavate went to Cambridge to study M.A in mathematics and earned Mathematical Tripos Wrangler. Pavate was married to Girijabai from Salanhalli village near Gokak. After returning from England, Pavate was appointed as Educational Commissioner of [[Bombay State|Bombay-Karnataka]]. In the year 1954, he served as the third vice-chancellor of the Karnataka University, Dharwar and continued until 1967. The rapid development of the institution is credited to him. In 1967 he was nominated as the Governor of Punjab, where he served till 1973. Dr Pavate returned to Bangalore, to serve Basava Samiti, Bangalore as advisor. He was instrumental in setting up Basava Bhavan, near Vidhana Soudha, Bangalore. He authored two books, "My days as Governor" and "My days as educational administrator". Dr Pavate died in Banglore on 31 January 1979 and was cremated in Mamdapur, which was his birthplace. DC Pavate visiting scholarship has been established starting 1999 at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge. It is awarded to outstanding graduates from Karnataka.[http://www.cambridge-india.org/funding-opportunities/dr-dc-pavate-memorial-visiting-fellowship Dr. D. C. Pavate Memorial Visiting Fellowship] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.winentrance.com/scholarships/Karnatak-University.html Dr. D. C. Pavate Memorial Fellowship to Cambridge] *[http://www.dharwad.com/univ.html Karnataka University] *[http://dcpcgadag.com/ D. C. Pavate College] *{{Coord|15.440583|74.985362|type:landmark_scale:2000_source:wikimapia}} Pavate statue *[http://www.kud.ernet.in/KU_constituent%20colleges/Science/karnataka%20Science%20college.htm Karnatak Science College] {{PadmaBhushanAwardRecipients 1960–69}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavate, D. C.}} [[Category:Lingayatism]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Bhushan in literature & education]] [[Category:Governors of Punjab, India]] [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:Kannada people]] [[Category:People from Belgaum district]] [[Category:Karnatak University faculty]]

revision.text:
[[File:Donyi Polo flag.jpg|thumb|Donyi-Polo flag. Seen over a house in [[Itanagar]], indicates that its inhabitants follow the religion.]] '''Donyi-Polo''' (also '''Donyi-Poloism'''){{refn|group=note|Other taxonomies used are: * '''Danyi-Piilo''', the [[Apatani people|Apatani]] variation.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 271</ref> * '''Sedism''', from the [[Adi people|Adi]] name of God, ''Sedi''.<ref>Rikam, 2005. pp. 120-121</ref> * '''Tanism''', for all [[Tani languages|Tani]] peoples, tracing their mythical ancestry to [[Abotani]].<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 130</ref> * '''Rangfraism''', from the [[Tangsa people|Tangsa]] name of God, ''Rangfrah''.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 261</ref><ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. pp. 274-275</ref> * '''Intayaism''', from the [[Mishmi people|Mishmi]] name of the Goddess, ''Intaya''.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 261</ref><ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. pp. 274-275</ref>}} is the designation given to the [[indigenous religion]]s, of [[animism|animistic]] and [[shamanism|shamanic]] type, of the [[Tani languages|Tani]] and other [[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]] peoples<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 118</ref> of [[Arunachal Pradesh]], in north-eastern [[India]].<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 117</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 47</ref> The name "Donyi-Polo" means "Sun-Moon", and was chosen for the religion in the process of its revitalisation and institutionalisation started in the 1970s in response to inroads made by [[Christianity]] and the possibility of absorption into [[Hinduism]].<ref>Dalmia, Sadana, 2012. pp. 44-45</ref>
The religion has developed a congregational system, hymns to be sung composed in the Tani ritual language of shamans, a formalised [[philosophy]]-[[theology]] and [[iconography]] of the gods<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 261</ref> and temples.<ref>Dalmia, Sadana, 2012. pp. 44-45</ref> The pioneer of the revival was [[Talom Rukbo]].<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 263</ref> Donyi-Polo is related to the Hemphu-Mukrang religion of the [[Karbi people|Karbi]] and the Nyezi-No of the [[Hruso people|Hruso]].
==Theology and cosmology==
===''Sedi'' and ''Keyum''=== In the Donyi-Polo belief, the [[Absolute (philosophy)|fountain god that begets the universe]] ([[God]] or the Godhead) is referred to as ''Sedi'' by the [[Minyong tribe|Minyong]] and ''[[Padam tribe|Padam]]'', ''Jimi'' by the [[Galo tribe|Galo]].<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 117</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. pp. 47-48</ref> All things and beings are parts of the body of ''Sedi'':<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 119</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. pp. 47-48</ref> in creation, the hair of ''Sedi'' becomes the plants of the earth, his tears become rain and water, his bones become rocks and stones, and his two eyes become ''Donyi'' (the Sun) and ''Polo'' (the Moon).<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 119</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. pp. 47-48</ref> ''Sedi'', after creation, is a ''[[deus otiosus]]'' but continues to observe creation through his eyes, his double aspect veiling-unveiling-revealing himself.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 119</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. pp. 47-48</ref>
In Galo beliefs, ''Jimi'' manifests as ''Melo'' (Sky) and ''Sidi'' (Earth), out of the interaction of which all things and beings are born, including ''Donyi'' and ''Polo''.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 119</ref> There are other myths explaining the meaning of the duality ''Donyi'' and ''Polo''.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 119</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. pp. 47-48</ref>
According to [[Talom Rukbo]]'s theology, all celestial bodies including Earth, all things, originate from one source, ''Keyum'' (nothingness or the vacuum).<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 120</ref> ''Donyi''-''Polo'' is the polar force that generates all stars; the physical Sun and Moon (respectively, ''Bomong'' and ''Boo'') near the Earth and humanity, are bodily manifestations of the universal unseen power ''Donyi''-''Polo'', with ''Bomong'' carrying out the centralising power of ''Donyi'', and ''Boo'' the ''Polo'' power of life-giving.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 120</ref>
===''Donyi'' and ''Polo''=== ''Donyi'' (Sun) and ''Polo'' (Moon)—which are, respectively, female and male in the Tibeto-Burman tradition; called ''Ane Donyi'' ("Mother Sun") and ''Abo Polo'' ("Father Moon")<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 48</ref>—constitute a notion similar to the [[yin and yang]] of [[Chinese culture]]. It is the analogy through which the Divinity (''Sedi'') can be described,<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref><ref>Rikam, 2005. pp. 118-119</ref> representing the way in which the divine principle manifests itself, that is: eternally veiling, unveiling and then revealing himself in nature; providing harmony and balance to the universe, for example in the alternation of light and darkness, heat and cool, or unity (analogically, the Sun of the daily sky) and multiplicity (analogically, the stars of the night sky).<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref>
The practical expression of the faith in Donyi-Polo can be found in the daily life and actions of people: they call themselves "''Donyi O, Polo Ome''", meaning "children of the sun and the moon".<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 50</ref> When a believer is distressed he invokes "''Donyi''-''Polo''".<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 50</ref> If a man is falsely accused of lying he invokes "''Donyi-e!''", "oh Sun!".<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 50</ref> All these are expressions of faith in Donyi-Polo upholding providently the world, rewarding the righteous and punishing wrong-doers.<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 50</ref> The divine pair is revered as the highest holy figure governing fate.<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 50</ref>
"Donyi-Polo" is also used in the sense of "truth" in sacral speech.<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 51</ref> "Donyi-Polo" is an epitome for wisdom, enlightenment, right conscience, truthfulness, and selflessness.<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 51</ref> Aware people are called "''Donyi''-''Polo Ome''", which means "children of truth".<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 51</ref> Elders are regarded as "''Donyi''-''Polo Abu''", "representatives of the truth".<ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 51</ref>
===Gods=== The followers of Donyi-Poloism worship a variety of gods and goddesses that enliven nature.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref> These gods are believed to partake in the universal balance of ''Donyi'' and ''Polo'', and to be multiple manifestations or identities of ''Sedi''—''Donyi''-''Polo'', each with specific functions and roles.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 270</ref> It is believed that they take care of the earth and humanity.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref> The main deities in Donyi-Polo are ''Donyi'' and ''Polo'', ''Kine Nane'', ''Doying Bote'', ''Pedong Nane'' and ''Guumin Soyin''.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 270</ref>
==''Abotani''== [[Tani languages|Tani-speaking]] peoples ([[Apatani people|Apatani]], [[Galo tribe|Galo]], [[Nishi people|Nishi]], [[Tagin people|Tagin]], [[Na people|Na]], [[Mishing people|Mishing]]; [[Adi people|Adi]]-[[Lhoba people|Lhoba]]) share a myth telling of their descendance from the [[progenitor]] [[Abotani]].<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 118</ref> Other [[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]] peoples of [[Arunachal Pradesh]] who share the Donyi-Polo faith don't subscribe to the descendance from Abotani.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 118</ref>
Abotani is thought to represent the evolution of the human being from the source ''Donyi'', ''Sedi'',<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 126</ref> the eye of the universe as important to man as the eye of the body.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 126</ref> The Divinity has projected man showing him the right way to go.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 126</ref>
==Conscience and ethics== Donyi-Poloists describe the "Donyi-Polo" nature of the universe as the eyes of human conscience.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref> Happiness is given through right action, and right action is that which follows the order of nature (Donyi-Polo).<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref>
Oshang Ering, a philosopher of the religion, has written that as the two objects in the sky (''Bomong'' and ''Boo'') focus light to enable us to see what is what, Donyi-Polo makes us aware of what is wrong and right.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref> Right conscience naturally prevails.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref> When a person does wrong things (acts against the natural order) and tries to hide it, or masks it as good, then the force of conscience (Donyi-Polo) imposes a psychological pression, and the wrong doer loses happiness.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref>
Right conscience naturally guides man.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref> According to the traditional belief, love, compassion, equality and selflessness are naturally ordained by Donyi-Polo; they are inscribed in nature.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 127</ref> The [[ethics|ethical]] dimension of Donyi-Polo also means purity, beauty, simplicity, and frankness.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref>
==Institution== On 28 August 1968, a meeting of [[Adi people|Adi]] intellectuals was held in [[Along, Arunachal Pradesh|Along]], [[West Siang district|West Siang]], to discuss countermeasures to be taken against the gradual erosion of indigenous identity and traditions attributed to [[India]]'s policy of integration of [[Arunachal Pradesh]], and particularly the rapid, aggressive and coercive proselytizing of [[Christianity]] in the area since the 1950s which has caused an enduring crisis in the cultural mosaic of the north-eastern state.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 261</ref> The meeting's aim was also that of uniting the Tibeto-Burman folks under a collective identity and values for a good life.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 263</ref><ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 270</ref>
[[Talom Rukbo]] emerged as the father of Donyi-Poloism, a term that was coined for the institutionalisation of the Tibeto-Burman folk religion.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. pp. 263-264</ref> According to Rukbo, the main reason of the easy erosion of the traditional culture was that it lacked a written literature.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 263</ref> So, with the aim of recovering the endangered rituals, prayers and hymns, within 1986 three major cultural organisations were founded: the Tani Jagriti Foundation, the Donyi-Polo Youth Federation and the Donyi-Polo Yelam Kebang.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref>
Rukbo expressed the need for institutionalisation of the traditional faith in these terms:<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref> :«''Tradition means the way of living of a society practicing its socio-religious culture, economic life, the way of preserving history, literature and all other norms of social life inherited from time immemorial which may be called social character and identity''».
Many Adi and Tani intellectuals reflected Rukbo's ideas, and these gradually spread across the tribes and even beyond the Tani people.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 264</ref> The 31 December, the day of establishment of the Donyi-Polo Yelam Kebang in 1986, has been made the "Donyi-Polo Day" celebrated each year.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref>
Since then, templar areas (''gangging'') have been consecrated, religious literature and prayer hymns have been collected and published.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 267</ref> To meet the growing number of adherents in the revival, the Donyi-Polo Yelam Kebang established orientation courses—which take place twice a year—and trained groups of youth to send back with books and icons to their home village, to encourage people to construct temples and conduct prayers.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 268</ref> During the last two decades the spiritual revival has spread all over Arunachal Pradesh.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 269</ref>
Supporters of the revival have coined the slogan «''Loss of culture is loss of identity''» which has become very popular. The indirect implication is that those who convert to [[Christianity]] lose their culture and hence their identity.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 274</ref>
===''Gangging''=== A ''gangging'' is a general name for a prayer place of the Donyi-Poloist faith, and especially in the [[Adi people|Adi]] areas.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref> The ''gangging'' as a [[sacred]] enclosure is a concept popularised by the Donyi-Polo Yelam Kebang since 1996.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref>
According to Talom Rukbo, the word ''gangging'' is derived from ''Gangging Siring'', the concept of a land or [[tree of life|holy tree]] that mediates between the spiritual and the natural worlds,<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref> and from which any thing, living or non-living, comes into existence.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 265</ref>
''Gangging'' congregants have to follow certain rules: for example, male members must sit on the left in rows, and female members on the right, cross-legged.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 267</ref> Within the prayer place, there should not be any noise during prayer except the sound of the hymns.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 267</ref> Prayers are organized in the prayer place on Sundays, and all of the ''gangging'' branches established in each of the villages under the Siang district are centrally regulated by the Donyi-Polo Yelam Kebang.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 267</ref> Through the prayer place, codified rituals and practices, and [[iconography|iconographies]] of the Gods and Goddesses have been introduced.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 267</ref>
===Ethnic variations=== In [[Galo tribe|Galo]] areas, the prayer place and community halls (''dere'') have come up under the patronage of the Donyi-Polo Welfare Association and they are being built since the 2000s.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 270</ref> Priests (''nyibu'') conduct prayers in the prayer place on Sundays.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 270</ref> In [[Apatani people|Apatani]] areas, the religion is called "Danyi-Piilo" and prayer place are called ''meder nello'' ("purified place"), the first of which was built in 2004<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 271</ref> Songs and prayers are collected in a prayer book called ''Lyambope''.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 271</ref> Donyi-Poloist prayer place in [[Nishi people|Nishi]] areas are called ''nyedar namlo'' ("pure place"), and also among them the movement has been started only in the early 2000s.<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. p. 271</ref>
More recently, the success of Donyi-Polo has crossed the Tani cultural borders inspiring the rise of Rangfraism among the [[Tangsa people|Tangsa]], and of Intayaism among the [[Mishmi people|Mishmi]], respectively in [[Changlang district|Changlang]] and [[Dibang Valley district|Dibang Valley]].<ref>Chaudhuri, 2013. pp. 274-275</ref>

The '''''Feriale Duranum''''' is a calendar of [[Religion in ancient Rome|religious observances]] for a Roman military garrison at [[Dura-Europos]] on the [[Euphrates]], [[Roman Syria]], under the reign of [[Severus Alexander]] (224–235 AD). The small [[papyrus]] roll was discovered among the documents of an [[Cohort (military unit)|auxiliary cohort]], the ''[[Cohors XX Palmyrenorum]]'' (Twentieth Cohort of [[Palmyra|Palmyrenes]]),{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|page=72}}{{sfnp|Hekster|2008|page=66}} in the Temple of [[Atargatis|Azzanathkona]].{{sfnp|Pollard|2000|page=142}} The calendar, written in [[Latin]], is arranged in four columns, with some gaps. It offers important evidence for the [[Religion in the ancient Roman military|religious life of the Roman military]] and the role of [[Imperial cult (ancient Rome)|Imperial cult]] in promoting loyalty to the [[Roman emperor]],{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|page=72}} and for the coexistence of Roman state religion and local religious traditions.{{sfnp|Dirven|1999|pages=184–185}}{{sfnp|Pollard|2000|page=143}}
[[Roman festivals|Festivals]] named include [[Quinquatria]] (a purification of arms), the [[Parilia|birthday of Rome]], [[Neptunalia]] and two [[Rosalia (festival)|Rosaliae]] at which the military standards were adorned with roses.{{sfnp|Hekster|2008|page=81}} The calendar prescribes sacrifices for [[List of Roman deities|deities of traditional Roman religion]] such as the [[Capitoline triad]] of [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]], and [[Minerva]], as well as [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] and [[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]].{{sfnp|Hekster|2008|page=81}} About twenty members of the imperial family are honored as ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#divus|divi]]'', divinized mortals, including six women and [[Germanicus]], who was never an emperor.{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|page=72}} Twenty-seven of the forty-three entries that remain legible pertain to Imperial cult.{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|page=72}} No Eastern [[mystery religions]], which were widely celebrated in the Empire during this period, nor local cults are recorded as an official observance of the army,{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|pages=72-73}} but the ''feriale'' was found in the temple with a [[wikt:dipinto|dipinto]] depicting a Roman officer offering incense to the local deity [[Iarhibol|Iarḥibol]], and Romans, including a standard-bearer with the cohort's ''[[vexillum]]'', standing before the altar of the Syrian gods Iarḥibol, [[Aglibol]] and [[Arsu|Arṣu]].{{sfnp|Dirven|1999|page=187}} It has also been argued that the three gods represent the emperors [[Pupienus]], [[Balbinus]], and [[Gordian III]].{{sfnp|Pollard|2000|page=143}} A copy of the calendar may have been issued to each unit throughout the Empire to further military cohesion as well as Roman identity among troops from other cultures.{{sfnp|Dirven|1999|pages=184–185}}<ref>{{harvp|Pollard|2000|pages=143}} (especially note 126), 146.</ref>
The cache of documents was discovered by a team of archaeologists from [[Yale University]] working at Dura-Europos in 1931–32.{{sfnp|Kreitzer|1996|page=72}} It was first published by [[Robert O. Fink|R. O. Fink]], A. S. Hooey, and W. S. Snyder (1940), "The ''Feriale Duranum''," ''Yale Classical Studies'' 7: 1–222.{{sfnp|Pollard|2000|page=142}}
In 2011, a facsimile of the partial document was part of the Dura-Europos exhibition at Boston College, and it contained the following translation:
:March 19, [[Quinquatria]], a supplication; until March 23, supplications
:April 4, for the birthday of [[Caracalla|Antonius Magnus]], an ox
:April 9, for the accession of the deified [[Septimius Severus|Pius Severus]], an ox
:April 11, for the birthday of [[Septimius Severus|Pius Severus]], an ox
:April 21, for the birthday of the Eternal City of [[ancient Rome|Rome]], a cow
:April 26, for the birthday of [[Marcus Aurelius|Marcus Antoninus]], an ox
:May 7, for the birthday of the deified [[Julia Maesa]], a supplication
:May 10 (?), for the [[Rosalia (festival)|Rose-festival of the Standards]], a supplication
:May 12, for the circus-races in honor of [[Mars (god)|Mars]], to Mars Ultor, a bull
:May 21, because the deified [[Septimius Severus|Pius Severus]] was saluted as "imperator"
:May 24, for the birthday of [[Germanicus|Germanicus Caesar]], a supplication
:May 31, for the [[Rosalia (festival)|Rose-festival of the Standards]], a supplication
:June 9, for the Vestalia, to [[Vesta (deity)|Vesta Mater]], a supplication
:June 26, because our lord [[Severus Alexander|Marcus Aurelius Severus Alexander]] was named Caesar, a bull
:July 1, because our lord [[Severus Alexander|Marcus Aurelius Severus Alexander]] our Augustus was designated consul for the first time, a supplication
:July 4, for the birthday of the deified [[Salonia Matidia|Matidia]], a supplication
:July 10, for the succession of the deified [[Antoninus Pius]], an ox
:July 12, for the birthday of the deified [[Julius Caesar|Julius]], an ox
:July 23, for the day of the [[Neptunalia]], a supplication and a sacrifice
:Aug 1, for the birthday of the deified [[Claudius]] and the deified [[Pertinax]], an ox and an ox
:Aug 5, for the circus-races in honor of [[Salus]], a cow.
:Aug [14-29], for the birthday of [[Julia Avita Mamaea|Mamaea Augustus]], mother of Augustus, a cow
:Aug [15-30], for the birthday of the deified [[Ulpia Marciana|Marciana]], a supplication

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} '''[[Gautama Buddha]]''', the founder of [[Buddhism]], is also venerated as a manifestation of God in [[Hinduism]] and the [[Bahá'í]] faith.<ref name="PSmith">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Manifestations of God |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 231}}</ref> Some Hindu texts regard Buddha as an [[Gautama Buddha in Hinduism|avatar of the god Vishnu]], who came to Earth to delude beings away from the Vedic religion.<ref>{{Cite book | year=1997 | chapter=Buddha as depicted in the Purāṇas | title=Encyclopaedia of Hinduism, Volume 7 | author1=Nagendra Kumar Singh | publisher=Anmol Publications PVT. LTD. | isbn=978-81-7488-168-7 | pages=260–275 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UG9-HZ5icQ4C&pg=PA260 | postscript=<!--None--> }}. List of Hindu scripture that declares Gautama Buddha as 9th Avatar of Vishnu is as follows [Harivamsha (1.41) Vishnu Purana (3.18) Bhagavata Purana (1.3.24, 2.7.37, 11.4.23 Bhagavata Purana 1.3.24 [http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/24/en1 Bhagavata Purana 1.3.24] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926235132/http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/24/en1 |date=26 September 2007 }}, Garuda Purana (1.1, 2.30.37, 3.15.26) Agni Purana (160.Narada Purana (2.72)Linga Purana (2.71) Padma Purana (3.252) etc. [http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/en1 Bhagavata Purana, Canto 1, Chapter 3] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521022342/http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/en1 |date=21 May 2013 }} - SB 1.3.24: "Then, in the beginning of Kali-yuga, the Lord will appear as Lord Buddha, the son of Anjana, in the province of Gaya, just for the purpose of deluding those who are envious of the faithful theist." ... The [[Bhavishya Purana]] contains the following: "At this time, reminded of the Kali Age, the god Vishnu became born as Gautama, the [[Shakyamuni]], and taught the Buddhist dharma for ten years. Then Shuddodana ruled for twenty years, and Shakyasimha for twenty. At the first stage of the [[Kali Yuga|Kali Age]], the path of the Vedas was destroyed and all men became Buddhists. Those who sought refuge with Vishnu were deluded." Found in Wendy O'Flaherty, ''Origins of Evil in Hindu Mythology.'' University of California Press, 1976, page 203. Note also SB 1.3.28: "All of the above-mentioned incarnations [avatars] are either plenary portions or portions of the plenary portions of the Lord [Krishna or Vishnu]"</ref> He is also regarded as a [[prophet]] by the [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alislam.org/library/books/revelation/part_2_section_2.html|title=Buddhism|publisher=Islam International Publications|accessdate=9 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alislam.org/introduction/index.html|title=An Overview|publisher=Alislam|accessdate=9 September 2010}}</ref>
==Hinduism== {{main|Gautama Buddha in Hinduism}} [[File:Avatarbuddha.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Some Hindus regard Buddha as the 9th [[Avatar]] of [[Vishnu]].]] Gautama Buddha is mentioned as an [[Avatar]] of [[Vishnu]] in the [[Puranic]] texts of [[Hinduism]].<ref>[http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/en1 Bhagavata Purana, Canto 1, Chapter 3] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521022342/http://srimadbhagavatam.com/1/3/en1 |date=21 May 2013 }} - SB 1.3.24: "Then, in the beginning of Kali-yuga, the Lord will appear as Lord Buddha, the son of Anjana, in the province of Gaya, just for the purpose of deluding those who are envious of the faithful theist." ... SB 1.3.28: "All of the above-mentioned incarnations [avatars] are either plenary portions or portions of the plenary portions of the Lord [Krishna or Vishnu]"</ref> In the [[Bhagavata Purana]] he is twenty fourth of twenty five avatars, prefiguring a forthcoming final incarnation. A number of [[Hindu]] traditions portray Buddha as the most recent of ten principal avatars, known as the [[Dashavatara]] (''Ten Incarnations of God'').
Siddhartha Gautama's teachings deny the authority of the [[Vedas]] and consequently [at least atheistic] Buddhism is generally viewed as a ''[[Nastika|nāstika]]'' school (heterodox, literally "It is not so"<ref>"in Sanskrit philosophical literature, 'āstika' means 'one who believes in the authority of the Vedas' or 'one who believes in life after death'. ('nāstika' means the opposite of these). The word is used here in the first sense." Satischandra Chatterjee and Dhirendramohan Datta. An Introduction to Indian Philosophy. Eighth Reprint Edition. (University of Calcutta: 1984). p. 5, footnote 1.</ref>) from the perspective of orthodox Hinduism.
Many of the eighteen orthodox Puranas mention the Buddha in a less favouring light. They present the birth of the Buddha as a ploy by the Supreme God Vishnu to corrupt demons and sway them from Vedic teachings. Only by leading them astray with his teachings could the demons be destroyed. This belief is sometimes associated with the Asuras of Tripura (the three citadels) as well as others. Literature from the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]], on the other hand, maintains that [[Krishna]] took the appearance of an atheistic teacher out of benevolence, in order to trick atheists into worshipping God (i.e., himself).
==Sikhism== Buddha is mentioned as the 23rd avatar of Vishnu in the [[Chaubis Avtar]], a composition in Dasam Granth traditionally and historically attributed to [[Guru Gobind Singh]].<ref>http://www.info-sikh.com/VVPage1.html</ref>
==Taoism, Confucianism and Shinto== {{main|Buddhism and Eastern teaching}} Some early Chinese Taoist-Buddhists thought the Buddha to be a reincarnation of [[Lao Tzu]].<ref>The Cambridge History of China, Vol.1, (The Ch'in and Han Empires, 221 BC—220 BC) {{ISBN|0-521-24327-0}} hardback</ref>
In Japan, since one of the symbols of [[Vairocana|Dainichi Nyorai]] (one of the non-historical buddhas of [[Mahayana]] Buddhism) was the sun, many equated [[Amaterasu]], the Sun Goddess, with a previous reincarnation (bodhisattva) of Dainichi Nyorai.
==Ahmadiyya Muslim Community== [[Mirza Tahir Ahmad]], the Fourth [[Khalifatul Masih|Caliph]] of the [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]], in his book ''[[Revelation, Rationality, Knowledge & Truth]]'', argues that Buddha was indeed a prophet of God who preached Monotheism. He quotes from the inscriptions on Ashoka's stupas which mention "Isa'na" which means God. He quotes, "'Thus spake Devanampiya Piyadasi: "Wherefore from this very hour, I have caused religious discourses to be preached, I have appointed religious observances that mankind, having listened thereto, shall be brought to follow in the right path, and give glory to God* (Is'ana)."<ref>[http://www.alislam.org/library/books/revelation/part_2_section_2.html ''Al-Islam.org''] Revelation, Rationality, Knowledge & Truth, Mirza Tahir Ahmad, Chapter, Buddhism.</ref> The Ahmadiyya hold the view that the Buddha was indeed a [[Prophets and messengers in Islam|Prophet of God]].
[[Mirza Tahir Ahmad]] has also stated that the Qur'anic figure called [[Dhul-Kifl]] may have been the Buddha in his book "An Elementary Study of Islam."<ref>http://www.alislam.org/books/study-of-islam/prophets.html</ref>
In fact, a verse in the Qur'an quotes that God has sent many prophets to thee (Humanity). However, only a few have been named. It is believed by some{{Who|date=September 2018}} that Buddha may (or may not) have been a Prophet of God sent to his people who taught Monotheism.
==Christianity== {{main|Buddhism and Christianity}} [[File:Christ et Buddha by Paul Ranson 1880.JPG|right|thumb|190px|''Christ and Buddha'' by [[Paul Ranson]], 1880]] The Greek legend of "[[Barlaam and Josaphat|Barlaam and Ioasaph]]", sometimes mistakenly attributed to the 7th century [[John of Damascus]] but actually written by the [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] monk [[Euthymius of Athos|Euthymius]] in the 11th century, was ultimately derived, through a variety of intermediate versions ([[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Georgian language|Georgian]]) from the life story of the Buddha. The king-turned-monk Ioasaph (Georgian ''Iodasaph'', Arabic ''Yūdhasaf'' or ''Būdhasaf'': Arabic "b" could become "y" by [[Arabic alphabet|duplication of a dot]] in handwriting) ultimately derives his name from the Sanskrit [[Bodhisattva]], the name used in Buddhist accounts for Gautama before he became a Buddha.<ref name="CatholicEncyclopedia">{{CathEncy|wstitle=Barlaam and Josaphat}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.wiekisource.org/wiki/1911_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica/Barlaam_and_Josaphat|title=Encyclopædia Britannica Article on Barlaam and Josaphat}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Barlaam and Ioasaph were placed in the Greek Orthodox calendar of [[saint]]s on 26 August, and in the West they were entered as "[[Barlaam and Josaphat]]" in the Roman Martyrology on the date of 27 November.
==Judaism== The story was translated into Hebrew in the 13th century by [[Abraham Ibn Chisdai]] (or Hasdai) as "Ben-Hamelekh Vehanazir" ("The Prince and the [[Nazirite]]").{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
==Bahá'í Faith== In the Bahá'í Faith, Buddha is classified as one of the [[Manifestations of God]] which is a title for a major prophet in the Bahá'í Faith.<ref>Hornby, Helen Bassett (1994). ''Lights of Guidance: A Bahá'í Reference File''. Bahá'í Publishing Trust (New Deli, India), [http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2&chapter=4#n1684 p. 502 (#1684)]. {{ISBN|81-85091-46-3}}</ref> Similarly, the [[Prophet]] of the Bahá'í Faith, [[Bahá'u'lláh]], is believed by Bahá'ís to be the [[Fifth Buddha]], among other prophetic stations.<ref>''The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book''. Bahá'í Publishing Trust (Wilmette, Illinois, USA), [http://bahai-library.com/writings/bahaullah/aqdas/kaall.html#233 p. 233 (#1684)]. {{ISBN|0-85398-999-0}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{More citations needed|January 2010|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox building |name = Dukh Nivaran Sahib
ਦੁਖ ਨਿਵਾਰਨ ਸਾਹਿਬ |image = Image:Dukh Nivaran 01.jpg |image_size = 275px |caption= Dukh Nivaran Sahib |coordinates = |location_town = [[Patiala]] |location_country = [[India]] |construction_start_date= |completion_date= |style = [[Sikh architecture]] }} '''Gurdwara Dukh Nivaran Sahib''' is situated in what used to be the village of Lehal, now part of [[Patiala]] city. ==History== [[File:Dukh Nivaran darbar sahib.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Darbar Sahib]] According to local tradition, supported by an old handwritten document preserved in the [[Gurdwara]], one Bhag Ram, a jhivar of Lehal, waited upon [[Sikh Gurus|ninth guru]] of [[Sikhs]] [[Guru Tegh Bahadur]] during his sojourn at Saifabad (now Bahadurgarh), and made the request that he might be pleased to visit and bless his village so that its inhabitants could be rid of a serious and mysterious sickness which had been their bane for a long time. The Guru visited Lehal on Magh sudi 5, 1728 Bikram/24 January 1672 and stayed under a banyan tree by the side of a pond.http://www.sgpc.net/historical-gurdwaras/tegh.asp#3 The sickness in the village subsided. The site where Guru Tegh Bahadur had sat came to be known as Dukh Nivaran, literally meaning ''eradicator of suffering''. Devotees have faith in the healing qualities of water in the sarovar attached to the shrine. Raja Amar Singh of Patiala (1748–82) had a garden laid out on the site as a memorial which he entrusted to [[Nihang]] Sikhs. Records of a court case in 1870 mention a Guru's garden and a Nihangs' well being in existence here.In 1920, during a survey for the proposed construction of [[Sirhind]]-[[Patiala]]-[[Jakhal]] railway line, it appeared that the banyan tree under which had sat Guru Tegh Bahadur would have to be removed. But men charged with felling it refused to touch it. Ultimately, [[Maharaja Bhupinder Singh]] ordered cancellation of the entire project. No gurudwara building had, however, been raised. It was only in 1930 that a committee was formed to collect funds and commence construction and was completed twelve years later in the year 1942. [[Maharaja Yadavindra Singh]] who was a devout Sikh built the present building and sarovar.http://www.patialaonline.co.in/attraction.php#c1 The Gurdwara when completed passed under the administrative control of the Patiala state government. It was later transferred to the Dharam Arth Board of the [[Patiala and East Punjab States Union]] and eventually to the [[Shiromani Gurudwara Prabandhak Committee]]. ==Gurdwara Dukh Nivaran Sahib Complex== [[File:Dukh Nivaran Sarovar.jpg|thumb|250px|right|''The sarovar adjacent to Gurdwara Dukh Nivaran, Patiala'']] [[File:Notice Board GDN.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Notice board depicting History of Gurdwara]] The building complex sprawls over several acres. The two storey gateway has a collapsible iron gate and black and white marble floor. On the left of the pathway leading to the principal building is a small marble shrine marking the site where Guru Tegh Bahadur had sat under the [[banyan tree]]. The central two storey building, with a domed pavilion on top, is on a raised base having an octagonal domed chamber at each corner. The pinnacled lotus dome on top has a round sun-window on each side with a curved coping, projected horizontally at the ends. There are decorative domed pavilions at the corners and lotus blossoms in leaf in the middle on top of the walls. The interior is paved with marble slabs in white and grey against black and white of the outer platform. The walls and pillars are also panelled with white marble slabs. The ceiling is decorated with stucco work in floral design. The [[Guru Granth Sahib]] is seated under a square canopy at the far end. The 75metre square sarovar, since considerably extended, is on the right and [[Guru ka Langar]] on the left as one enters. The Gurdwara is administered by the [[SGPC|Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee]]. A big gathering is held on the fifth day of the light half of each [[lunar month]]. The festival of the year is [[Basant Panchmi]] which marks the day of Guru Tegh Bahadur's visit. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.apnapatiala.com/tourist-destinations/gurdwara-shri-dukhniwaran-sahib/ Gurdwara Dukhniwaran Sahib Information] * [http://www.dukhniwaransahib.com Dukhniwaran Sahib Website] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/59151633@N00/tags/gurdwaradukhnivaran/ Photos relating to this Gurdwara on Flickr] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/oochappan/tags/gurdwaradukhnivaran/ Photos of Gurdwara Dukh Nivaran Sahib] {{coord|30.3471|N|76.3961|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Gurdwaras in Punjab, India]] [[Category:Sikh places]] [[Category:Patiala]]

{{For|the X-Files episode|Hell Money}}
[[Image:Burning-money-and-yuanbao-at-the-cemetery-3249.JPG|thumb|250px|Joss paper money being burnt near a grave along with joss ''[[yuanbao (currency)|yuanbao]]'' during the Chinese [[Ghost Festival]].]]
'''Hell money''' is a form of [[joss paper]] printed to resemble [[legal tender]] [[bank notes]].The notes are not an official form of recognized [[currency]] or legal tender since their sole intended purpose is to be offered as [[burnt offering]]s to the [[ancestor veneration|deceased]] as a superstitious solution to resolve their ancestors’ financial problems. This custom has been practiced by the modern Chinese and across [[East Asia]] since the late 19th century.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Singapore: State of the Art |last= Yogerst |first=Joseph R. |publisher= R Ian Lioyd Productions Ltd |year=2005 |isbn=978-9810465896 |pages=38}}</ref> Early 20th century examples bore resemblance to minor commercial currency of the type issued by businesses across China until the mid-1940s.<ref>Smith, Ward & Matravers, Brian (1970). Chinese Banknotes, p.144. Shirjieh Publishers, Menlo Park, California</ref>
The identification of this type of joss paper as "'''hell bank notes'''" or "hell money" is largely a [[Western culture|Western]] construct, since these items are simply regarded as yet another form of joss paper (冥幣, 陰司紙, 紙錢, or 金紙) in [[East Asia]]n cultures and have no special name or status.
==The name "hell"== The word ''[[hell]]'' on hell bank notes refers to ''[[Diyu]]'' ({{zh|t=地獄|s=地狱|p=dìyù}}, "underworld prison"; also 地府, ''dìfǔ'', "underworld court"). These words are printed on some notes. In traditional Chinese belief, it is thought to be where the souls of the dead are first judged by the Lord of the Earthly Court, Yan Wang. After this particular judgement, they are either escorted to heaven or sent into the maze of underworld levels and chambers to atone for their sins. People believe that even in the earthly court, spirits need to use money.<ref>[http://www.joelscoins.com/catpm.htm World Paper Money<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A popular story says that the word ''hell'' was introduced to China by [[Christian]] [[missionaries]], who preached that all non-Christian Chinese people would go to hell after death. The word "Hell" was thus misinterpreted to be the proper English term for the afterlife and hence adopted as such. Some printed notes attempt to correct this by omitting the word "hell" and sometimes replacing it with "heaven" or "paradise". These particular bills are usually found in [[Joss paper|joss]] packs meant to be burned for Chinese deities, and usually have the same design as hell bank notes but with different colours.
==Designs== [[File:GT-Höllengeld Shenzhen 1.jpg|thumb|left|A Chinese "hell banknote"]]
Earlier examples of these notes were issued in denominations of 5 and 10 yuan and upwards, with such amounts being considered adequate until inflation took hold within China from 1944. The soaring denominations of authentic currency was soon reflected in that issued for the afterlife, and after 1945 the majority of Hell banknotes were issued in denominations of $10,000 or higher. These earlier issues more commonly depict landscape scenes, temples or trains, and the numerous varieties may literally number into the millions.<ref>Smith, Ward & Matravers, Brian (1970). Chinese Banknotes, p.144-145. Shirjieh Publishers, Menlo Park, California</ref>
Modern Hell bank notes are known for their large denominations, ranging from $10,000 to several billions. The obverse usually bears an effigy of the [[Jade Emperor]], the presiding monarch of heaven in [[Taoism]]; his signature, [[Romanization of Chinese|romanised]] as ''Yu Wong'' or ''Yuk Wong''; and the countersignature of [[Yama (Buddhism and Chinese mythology)|Yanluo, King of Hell]] (閻羅). There is usually an image of the Bank of Hell on the reverse of the notes.
A commonly sold Hell bank note is the $10,000 note that is styled after the old [[United States]] [[Federal Reserve Note]]. The obverse contains, apart from the portrait of the Jade Emperor, the seal of the Bank of Hell consisting of a picture of the bank itself. Many tiny, faint "Hell Bank Note"s are scattered on the back in yellow. These are sold in packs of 50 to 150, and are wrapped in [[cellophane]].
Stores that specialize in selling ritual items, such as the [[religious goods store]]s in [[Malaysia]], also sell larger and elaborately decorated notes that have a larger denomination than the usual $10,000 note. Some bills do not portray the Jade Emperor, and portray other famous figures from Chinese mythology instead, such as the [[Eight Immortals]], the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]], [[Yama]], or images of dragons. Some even portray famous people who are deceased, such as US President [[John F. Kennedy]], [[Albert Einstein]] and [[Marilyn Monroe]].
{{clear}}
== Customs == When [[money burning|burning the notes]], the notes are placed as a loose bundle, in a manner considered respectful. Alternatively, in some customs, each bank note may be folded in a specific way before being tossed into the fire because of the belief that burning real money brings bad luck.
While the custom of burning "hell bank notes" remains legal in China, the [[Ministry of Civil Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Civil Affairs]] has as of 2006 banned the practice of "vulgar" burnt-offerings for the deceased, which include paper "''luxury villas, sedan cars, mistresses, and other messy sacrificial items''", as well as [[Viagra]] and simulated models of "karaoke hostesses" and "Supergirls" based on the hit TV contest ''[[Super Girl (TV series)|Mongolian Cow Yoghurt Supergirl]]'', according to the Ministry, in effort to eradicate "[[feudal]]" and [[superstition|superstitious]] behavior.<ref>http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-04/25/content_576881.htm</ref>
==See also== * [[Ancestor worship]] * [[Ghost Festival]] * [[Joss paper]] * [[Religious goods store]]
